definition: abbr. for 書經|书经[Shu1 jing1]
to be born/to give birth/life/to grow/raw/uncooked/student
lit. pale-faced scholar (idiom); young and inexperienced person without practical experience/still wet behind the ears

sentences.english: The scholar is subjected to this stroke, a disease not.
sentences.chinese: 书生受此打击，一病不起。

sentences.english: Don't be so bookish and unrealistic.
Shusheng swerved the car to the left and that swerve saved his life.
sentences.chinese: 书生突然把车向左转，而这一举动挽救了他的性命。

sentences.english: Your Majesty, since my 'Evil Sword' is powerful.
sentences.chinese: 皇爷，就是因为书生夺命剑威力太惊人。

sentences.english: So, on the weapon list, the Evil Scholar is the 1st runner-up.
sentences.chinese: 所以当今兵器谱上，书生夺命剑是排行第三。

sentences.english: In Meilong Town, Wang Xun is the most brilliant intellectual.
sentences.chinese: 梅陇镇上，王洵是最有才华的书生。

sentences.english: A soldier of dumpy scholar shape say.
sentences.chinese: 一个矮胖的书生模样的士兵说道。

sentences.english: Then White Snake Spirit fell in love with an intellectual and gave birth to a son.
sentences.chinese: 白蛇精与一位书生相爱并生一子。

sentences.english: Evil Scholar, you trapped my dad in te duel.
sentences.chinese: 夺命书生，当年你用计打赢了我爹。

sentences.english: When the scholar revisits their first meeting place, he feels heartbreaking.
sentences.chinese: 当书生白鹤再次回到了当初与爱人相遇的地方。

sentences.english: He couldn't imagine 'Evil Scholar' ruined the steel made spear-head.
sentences.chinese: 你爹锁有想到夺命书生连纯钢制造的枪头都拆得断。

sentences.english: Then I love leaving monk and scholar said that" if life magic".
sentences.chinese: 然后我特爱离开时和尚跟书生说的那段“幻若人生”。

sentences.english: Never be so bookish and naive as to treat complex class struggle as a simple matter.
sentences.chinese: 切不可书生气十足，把复杂的阶级斗争看得太简单了。

sentences.english: The soldier of dumpy scholar shape hurriedly take out notes bottom.
sentences.chinese: 矮胖的书生模样的士兵赶紧掏出笔记下。

sentences.english: There used to be a scholar, and fiancee herself in a certain period on a certain day of marriage.
sentences.chinese: 从前有个书生，和未婚妻约好在某年某月某日结婚。

definition: lit. pale-faced scholar (idiom); young and inexperienced person without practical experience/still wet behind the ears
a person who has passed the county level imperial exam (historical)/scholar/skillful writer/fine talent
plain cotton clothing/(literary) the common people
